IMAGE-HIGH-RES MOLCAA 8503 S1381-1169(12)00254-3 10.1016/j.molcata.2012.08.009 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 XRD patterns due to the ZrO2 (A) and WO3/ZrO2 catalysts (B). Fig. 2 SEM images of the catalysts. (a) ZrO2973, (b) 2.5W/ZrO2973, and (c) 10W/ZrO2973. Fig. 3 TPD spectra of WO3/ZrO2 catalysts. (a) NH3-TPD and (b) CO2-TPD. Fig. 4 Activity at 593K over pure WO3 and ZrO2 catalysts. Reaction conditions: GHSV=1000−1, P =0.5MPa, H2S/DMS=4.0, and catalyst: 2mL. Fig. 5 Catalytic performance of the WO3/ZrO2 catalysts for the thiolation of DMS with H2S to MT. Reaction conditions: GHSV=1000−1, P =0.5MPa, H2S/DMS=4.0, and catalyst: 2mL. Fig. 6 XPS spectra of Zr 4p and W 4f region for 5W/ZrO2973. (a) Fresh 5W/ZrO2973, (b) after reaction at 593K for 3h, (c) after reaction at 593K for 3h, then calcined at 973K in air for 3h. Fig. 7 Effect of water content on the MT yield. (■) 5W/ZrO2973, (●) 10W/ZrO2973. Reaction conditions: reaction temperature=593K, GHSV=1000−1, P =0.5MPa, H2S/DMS=4.0, and catalyst: 2mL. Fig. 8 Catalytic performance for the 5W/ZrO2973 catalyst as a function of time on stream. Reaction conditions: reaction temperature=633K, GHSV=1000−1, P =0.5MPa, H2S/DMS=4.0, and catalyst: 2mL. Table 1 Physicochemical properties of tungsten–zirconium mixed oxides. Graphical abstract Highlights ► The DMS and H2S were used to synthesize MT, an important chemical intermediate. ► The WO3/ZrO2 catalyst was first applied to the thiolation of DMS. ► The effect of water on the thiolation of DMS to MT was studied. The thiolation of dimethyl sulfide with H2S over a variety of tungsten–zirconia (WO3/ZrO2) catalysts with different contents of WO3 was studied. The maximum yield of methanethiol was obtained at the reaction temperature of 633K in the presence of 10wt.%WO3/ZrO2 catalyst. XRD, BET and TPD characterization results reveal that supporting WO3 species on ZrO2 gives rise to the improvement of both in structure stability and surface acidity. The MT yield increased first and then decreased with the increase of reaction temperature for all of the catalysts due to the decomposition of methanethiol and dimethyl sulfide. The optimum loading of WO3 was found to be 5–10wt.% (with a surface density of 3.5–4.5w-atomnm−2). Furthermore, the WO3/ZrO2 catalyst exhibits high resistance to water. Keywords Dimethyl sulfide Methanethiol Thiolation WO3/ZrO2 1 Introduction Methanethiol (CH3SH, MT) is an important chemical intermedium widely used in the production of pesticides, pharmaceuticals, petrochemicals, and especial for methionine synthesis [1,2]. During the last few years, with increasing stringently in the demand for methionine, there is a growing demand for methanethiol in order to meet the requirements [3,4]. The synthesis of methanethiol has received global attention, by now; several routes for its generation have been explored [5–12]. Industrially, methanethiol is mainly synthesized by thiolation of methanol with H2S, accompanying with the formation of dimethyl sulfide (CH3SCH3, DMS), a major byproduct [5]. However, dimethyl sulfide was incinerated as a wastegas generally. Beach [7] proposed first to recover dimethyl sulfide and used it as a feed for methanethiol synthesis, which performs in an independent by-pass reactor, during the synthesis of CH3SH from CH3OH and H2S, in such a way that the byproduct DMS can be converted to more valuable product MT. This is economically as well as environmentally attractive for better carbon management. The catalysts for this reaction were solid acid catalysts like γ-Al2O3 and P promoted Al2O3 [8,9]. The γ-Al2O3 catalyst is active; nevertheless, the major limitation for the usage of γ-Al2O3 is the existence of water in the recovered dimethyl sulfide, in which the content of water can achieve 5%, thereby loses its activity because of its hydrophilic nature. (1) CH3SCH3 +H2S→2CH3SH WO3/ZrO2 catalysts have received much attention in the recent catalysis field [13–16]. Hino and Arata [17] found that tungsten oxide-supported zirconia possesses appropriate superacid sites and smaller pore volume in comparison with other acid catalysts such as alumina or zeolite, and its application leads to effective downsizing of the reaction unit. Furthermore, the catalysts are extremely stable at high temperature in H2, O2 or H2O atmospheres [18,19]. Therefore, it is promising one to be used as a novel catalyst for the reaction of DMS with H2S. In the present work, we aimed to study the thiolation of DMS in the presence of pure ZrO2 and WO3/ZrO2 catalysts. The effect of catalyst preparation conditions, i.e. calcination temperature and tungsten loading on the catalyst performance was intensively studied. In addition, the effect of water content in the system on the reaction performance of the catalysts was explored as well. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of the ZrO2 support ZrO2 was prepared by the reverse precipitation method. Appropriate amount of 0.1M aqueous solution of zirconyl chloride (ZrOCl2·8H2O, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) was added dropwise to ammonium hydroxide solution (NH4OH, 25%, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.) at room temperature under well-stirring. The pH of the solution was controlled at 9, when a buoyant white powder immediately produced. After stirring for 6h at room temperature, the precipitate was evaporated in oil bath at 373K, and then washed with deionized water five times, following by drying overnight at 383K to generate a sample Zirconium hydroxide Zr(OH)4. Finally, the sample was devised into several parts and calcined respectively at different temperatures (773, 873, 973, 1073 and 1173K) for 3h to get ZrO2 samples. The samples are designated as ZrO2773, ZrO2873, ZrO2973, ZrO21073 and ZrO21173. 2.1.2 Preparation of the WO3/ZrO2 catalysts The WO3/ZrO2 catalysts with various weight percentages (2.5, 5.0, 7.5 and 10%) were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation in ammonium metatungstate solution (precursor (NH4)10W12O41·5H2O, 98% purity). The Zirconium hydroxide Zr(OH)4 sample was impregnated in the aqueous solution of calculated ammonium metatungstate. Then, the sample was dried overnight at 383K and calcined at 973K for 3h. The catalyst with x wt.% of WO3 was designated as xW/ZrO2; for example, 10wt.%WO3 supported on ZrO2973 is expressed as 10W/ZrO2973. 2.2 Reaction conditions DMS conversion reaction was conducted in a glass tubular fixed bed reactor with an internal diameter of 10mm typically, 2.0mL of the catalyst with 20–40 mesh was filled into the reactor, with a thin layer of glass fiber and a layer of quartz powder (20–40 mesh) covered on the catalyst. Before experiment, the catalyst was sulfurized with H2S for 1h at 673K for activating; the H2S flow rate was maintained by mass flow controller (Beijing Seven star, D08-1F). Then the sulfurized catalyst was tested at different temperatures (553, 573, 593, 613, 633, 653, 673 and 693K) in turn, and the system pressure was held at 0.5MPa with the aid of a back-pressure regulator. The DMS solution was injected into the catalyst bed by a precision metering pump (Beijing Satellite Manufactory, 2ZB-1L10). The outlet stream temperature was kept at 400K with heater band, and the effluent was analyzed by an on-line gas-chromatograph equipped with a Porapak Q (Ф2m×3mm) column connected to a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). To study the effect of H2O on the activity of the catalyst for the reaction, DMS with different contents of water, which was incorporated into DMS in advance by using a precision metering pump (Beijing Satellite Manufactory, 2ZB-1L10), was used as feedstock. 2.3 Catalyst characterization XRD measurements were performed on a Panalytical X’pert PRO X-ray diffractometer utilizing monochromatic Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.15418nm, tube voltage: 40kV, tube current: 30mA) in the 2θ range from 10° to 70°. The morphology of the catalyst was observed on field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, LEO1530). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Phi Quantera spectrometer equipped with an aluminum anode (AlKα=1486.6eV) operated at 25W (15kV, 1.67mA). The surface areas of the catalysts were measured using nitrogen adsorption at 77K with a Micromeritics Tristar 3000 surface area and pore analyzer. Prior to N2 physisorption measurement, all samples were degassed at 393K for 1h and then evacuated at 573K for 3h to remove physically adsorbed impurities. The actual content of tungsten oxide in xW/ZrO2 samples were determined by a Bruker S8 TIGER X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectrometer. NH3 and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) were performed in a quartz tube reactor filled with 80mg catalyst. For NH3-TPD experiment, the catalyst was pretreated in Ar at 673K for 1h, then cooled to 323K, at which ammonia was adsorbed for about 0.5h in an ammonia stream of 30mLmin−1. Loosely bound NH3 was removed by Ar sweeping at 323K, and then the temperature was increased to 973K at a heating rate of 10Kmin−1. The desorbed NH3 was monitored with a MS signal of m/e =16 and 17 in multiple ion detection (MID) mode. So did the CO2-TPD experiment as NH3-TPD with CO2 substituting for NH3. The CO2-TPD experiment was conducted from 323 to 873K. Desorbed CO2 component was monitored with a MS signal of m/e =44 in MID mode. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural properties The main physicochemical properties of the tungsten–zirconium mixed oxides are presented in Table 1 . The surface density of W species (w-atomnm−2) was calculated from Eq. (2) [15,20]. Increasing the calcination temperature of WO3-free zirconia led to a continuous decrease in the surface area owing to the sintering and crystallizing of amorphous zirconia support and significant pore collapse [14,16]; however, the surface area increased as increasing the WO3 loading at 973K, which can be attributed to the decrease of ZrO2 sintering rate caused by WO3 adding, meanwhile, the high resistance against ZrO2 sintering tends to getting finer pores. (2) S W = WC × ( 6.02 × 10 23 ) 100 × FW WO 3 × ( S BET × 10 18 ) where S W: W surface density (w-atomnm−2), WC: WO3 content (wt.%), FW WO 3 : formula weight of WO3 (231.8gmol−1), S BET: surface area (m2 g−1). The XRD patterns arising from ZrO2 catalysts calcined at the temperatures from 773 to 1173K and the WO3/ZrO2 catalysts with different WO3 concentrations are shown in Fig. 1(A) and (B). It can be seen that the crystallinity of ZrO2 in monoclinic phase increased with increasing the support calcination temperature. When WO3 was loaded onto ZrO2, the ratio of monoclinic phase to tetragonal phase decreased with increasing WO3 loading at 973K, providing further evidence of the stabilizing effect of surface WO3. These changes in the phase-transformation observed according to support calcination temperature and tungsten oxide loading are consistent with those reported in the literature [21–24]. No crystalline WO3 phase (2θ =23.2°, 23.7°, and 24.3°) can be detected even if the WO3 content being as high as 10wt.%, indicating that tungsten oxide was present in a highly dispersed manner. The SEM micrographs (Fig. 2 ) for ZrO2 and WO3/ZrO2 catalysts show similar quasi spherical morphological feature and the WO3/ZrO2 catalysts exhibit better uniformity, suggesting that tungsten species over throughout zirconia were well dispersed and could not crystallize separately. 3.2 Surface acid–base properties The intensities and quantities of acidic and basic sites on the catalysts were measured by NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD techniques, respectively; the experiment results obtained are presented in Fig. 3 . In contrast with pure ZrO2, the four WO3/ZrO2 catalysts mainly exhibit two peaks on the NH3-TPD curves. The low-temperature peak is assigned to ammonia desorbed from the weaker acid sites centered at around 400K, and the shoulder peak is due to ammonia desorbed from the stronger acid sites between 500 and 650K. The NH3-TPD spectra revealed that as the WO3 content increased, the areas of the TPD spectra increased, suggesting that the doping amount of tungsten oxide in the range of 2.5–10wt.% was responsible for the acidity and determined the quantities of surface acidic sites. On the other hand, the CO2 desorption occurred at the relatively low temperatures ranging from 330 to 390K, which can be assigned to weak basic sites for all of the catalysts. Notably, the area below the curves decreased as the WO3 content increased, which indicates that the surface basicity decreased due to the loading of tungsten oxide, the decrease trend is particularly significant for the 10W/ZrO2973. 3.3 Performance of pure WO3 and ZrO2 The reaction of H2S and DMS was carried out at 593K over pure WO3 and ZrO2 calcined at different temperatures. The initial activities and the activities after 3h reaction are summarized in Fig. 4 . The initial activity of pure WO3 was found to be maximal among these catalysts, but remarkable deactivation occurred in 3h time on stream. Calcining at lower temperatures (773–973K) made all of the ZrO2 catalysts showed a moderate conversion of DMS at about 15%; however, the conversion of DMS decreases for the catalysts calcined at higher temperatures (1073–1173K), this phenomenon can be due to the decrease in the catalyst surface area. Fortunately, the deactivation did not occur on the ZrO2 series in 3h time on stream. The formation of coke was confirmed to be the reason for the deactivation, the observation on the quick deactivation of pure WO3 may be attributed to coke deposition which cannot be removed immediately from the surface [25,26]. According to above results, a series of tungsten oxide catalysts with different tungsten contents loaded on ZrO2973 were investigated hereafter in detail. 3.4 Catalytic activity of WO3/ZrO2 Fig. 5 shows the effect of W contents on the performance of WO3/ZrO2 catalysts. The 10W/ZrO2973 catalyst exhibits the highest conversion of DMS, while the MT yield increased first and then decreased for all of the catalysts. The thiolation of DMS to MT is a simple reaction at relative low temperature with unique product MT [8,9,27,28], further increasing in reaction temperature is expected to aggravate the decomposition of DMS and MT themselves, generating a series of low hydrocarbon compounds (CH4, C2H6), element sulfur and carbon, as a result, lowering the MT yield. The tungsten oxide-supported ZrO2 catalysts exhibit higher conversion of DMS and yield of MT at relative lower reaction temperature in comparison with pure ZrO2973 sample, but when the reaction temperature rose up to 653K, the MT yield decreased fast for the strong decrease of the selectivity toward MT. This suggests that the catalysts with high content of WO3 own more acid sites, which contributed to violent decomposition of dimethyl sulfide and methanethiol, and decreased MT yield rapidly. We tested the 15W/ZrO2973 and 20W/ZrO2973 samples at 633K, and found that they got a DMS conversion close to 10W/ZrO2973, but the MT selectivity of these two catalysts were 88% and 84%, respectively. So, the optimum loading of WO3 was confirmed to be 5–10wt.%(with a surface density of 3.5–4.5w-atomnm−2). Fig. 6 shows XPS spectra due to the WO3/ZrO2 catalyst. Based on the XPS studies, most tungsten oxidation states in WO3/ZrO2 were found to be W6+, W5+and W4+ [29–31]. After reaction, the W6+ and W5+ cations totally transformed into W4+ cation, suggesting that the W4+ species participated in thiolation of DMS. Compared the curve (c) with (a), We found that after recalcined in air, the amount of W6+ cation seems to increase in contrast to the sample before reaction, meanwhile, the peak area of Zr4+ increases, suggesting that the recalcination may weaken the interaction between ZrO2 and WO3. However, the activity did not change, so we use the recalcined sample in the next water-adding test. 3.5 Effect of water content on the thiolation of DMS to MT over 5W/ZrO2973 and 10W/ZrO2973 It is well established that water present in feedstock exerts negative effect on the acid-catalyzed reactions [22,32]. In the γ-Al2O3 system, the presence of water during the thiolation reaction results in hydrolysis reaction, which eventually reduces the MT yield and speeds up the deactivation. Hence, in this study, the effect of water content (0–10%) added on the thiolation of DMS to MT was investigated at 593K. The results are shown in Fig. 7 . Fig. 7 indicates that the presence of water indeed lowered the yield of MT, especially when the water content is more than 5%, although the decreasing proportion is acceptable. Chu et al. [15] have demonstrated that WO3/ZrO2 have excellent surface hydrophobicity (the reciprocal of the density of water adsorbed). According to the reaction of H2S and DMS, the hydrophobic nature of the WO3/ZrO2 catalyst may reasonably guarantee the access of dimethyl sulfide to active sites and suppress the poisoning effect of water. 3.6 Effect of reaction time on the thiolation of DMS to MT Fig. 8 shows the effect of reaction time on the DMS conversion and MT selectivity catalyzed by 5W/ZrO2973 sample at 633K. It can be seen from the plot that a plateau of DMS conversion is attained in a short time of reaction (1h); the DMS conversion does not increase much with further increase in the reaction time even up to 12h. On the other hand, the MT selectivity maintained at a high and stable level for the whole 12h. 4 Conclusions Supporting WO3 species on ZrO2 gives rise to the improvements of both in structure stability and surface acidity. The activity of the series of WO3/ZrO2 catalysts increased remarkably depending upon the content of WO3 doped, The MT yield increased first and then decreased with the increase of reaction temperature especially for 10W/ZrO2973, the optimum loading of WO3 was found to be 5–10wt.% (with a surface density of 3.5–4.5w-atomnm−2). Furthermore, the WO3/ZrO2 catalyst exhibits high resistance to water, consequently, kept considerable yield of MT in the presence of water. coredata.dc:description: The thiolation of dimethyl sulfide with H2S over a variety of tungsten–zirconia (WO3/ZrO2) catalysts with different contents of WO3 was studied. The maximum yield of methanethiol was obtained at the reaction temperature of 633K in the presence of 10wt.%WO3/ZrO2 catalyst. XRD, BET and TPD characterization results reveal that supporting WO3 species on ZrO2 gives rise to the improvement of both in structure stability and surface acidity. The MT yield increased first and then decreased with the increase of reaction temperature for all of the catalysts due to the decomposition of methanethiol and dimethyl sulfide. The optimum loading of WO3 was found to be 5–10wt.% (with a surface density of 3.5–4.5w-atomnm−2). Furthermore, the WO3/ZrO2 catalyst exhibits high resistance to water.
coredata.dc:title: Thiolation of dimethyl sulfide to methanethiol over WO3/ZrO2 catalysts
